unnormalised: These "Healthcare and Insurance Identifiers," as the official types call them, are super important. They're designed to make sure hospitals, clinics, and insurance companies can quickly and accurately identify you and access your medical history. This cuts down on wait times and minimizes the risk of errors, which can be a HUGE deal when it comes to your health. Imagine someone getting the wrong medication because they mixed up your file with someone else's. Nightmare fuel!

unnormalised: In India, we've got a few different systems already in place. There’s the Ayushman Bharat Health Account (ABHA), which is basically a 14 digit number given to everyone. It's supposed to link all your health records. My neighbor, Sharma uncle, has ABHA: 12345678901234, he said it was easy to get.

unnormalised: Then, you've got your insurance policy number, which is different depending on which company you're with. ICICI Lombard for example, will have numbers like ICICL/HLTH/2024/007 or something. Plus, if you're enrolled in any government health schemes, like the ESIC (Employee's State Insurance Corporation) scheme, you’ll have an ESIC number. Mine is something like 12-34567890-123. My brother told me to keep it handy.
